prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Specific factors articulated by the Panel—Conservation of parties' resources

para.paratext: The Panel specifically relied on the fact that transfer would “conserve the resources of the parties” in a decision on whether transfer should be ordered.[1] This factor is implicit in many of the Panel's decisions, and can be viewed as a refinement of the discretionary decision to be made after the Panel has found that the statutory prerequisites to transfer have been met. In particular, this factor appears to encompass and elaborate on the statutory requirement that transfer “advance the just and efficient conduct” of the litigation.[2] In other cases the Panel viewed transfer as necessary to conserve the resources of not only the parties, but also of the judiciary and the attorneys for the parties.[3]

A concern similar to conservation of the parties resources is the recognition that in some cases there will be limited resources to compensate parties entitled to compensation. In that circumstance, centralization may be justified as a tool to ensure that all claimants are treated equitably, and that there will not be a “run on the bank.”[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

In re Air Crash at Dallas/Fort Worth Airport on Aug. 2, 1985, 623 F. Supp. 634, 635 (J.P.M.L. 1985). See also In re Gross Common Carrier, Inc., Freight Undercharge Claims Litigation, 843 F. Supp. 1506 (J.P.M.L. 1994); In re Cargo Losses From Gulf Fleet 265 in Dec. 1990, 142 F.R.D. 182 (J.P.M.L. 1992).
This requirement of the statute is discussed in § 5:6.

See, e.g., In re Neurontin Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Pineapple Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Foundry Resins Antitrust Litigation, 342 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Rail Collision Near Chase, Md. on Jan. 4, 1987, 661 F. Supp. 69 (J.P.M.L. 1987); In re Dow Chemical Co. Sarabond Products Liability Litigation, 650 F. Supp. 187, 188 (J.P.M.L. 1986); In re Air Crash Disaster at Gander, Newfoundland, on Dec. 12, 1985, 633 F. Supp. 50 (J.P.M.L. 1986).

See In re Gerova Financial Group, Ltd., Securities Litigation, 816 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (Panel notes in ordering transfer that there is a possible limited fund, and that centralization avoids depleting fund.).
